contents.title: Get Started
contents.description: @nuxtjs/supabase is a Nuxt module for first class integration with Supabase.

children.value: is a Nuxt module for first class integration with Supabase.
For integrating Supabase with Nuxt 2, checkout

props.className: language-bash shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code: npx nuxi@latest module add supabase

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight

SUPABASE_KEY="<your_key>"

children.value: Alternatively, you can prefix the env variables with
You can configure the supabase module by using the

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight

children.value: The unique Supabase URL which is supplied when you create a new project in your project dashboard.
Supabase 'anon key', used to bypass the Supabase API gateway and interact with your Supabase database making use of user JWT to apply RLS Policies.
Supabase 'service role key', has super admin rights and can bypass your Row Level Security.
Redirect automatically to the configured login page if a non authenticated user is trying to access a guarded. You can disable all redirects by setting this option to false.

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
redirectOptions: {
    login: '/login',
    callback: '/confirm',
    include: undefined,
    exclude: [],
    cookieRedirect: false,
  }

contents.title: Authentication
contents.description: Authenticate your user thanks to the PKCE Oauth protocol that enables secure exchange of refresh and access tokens between an application and the authorization server

children.value: With the default options, the module requires a log-in page and a confirm page to handle the
. If you want to understand how it works under the hood, you can read this
All you need to do is to create a
For advanced users who want to implement the auth behaviour themselves, you can disable or override the

Each time a user is trying to access a page that needs authentication, he will automatically be redirected to the configured log in page. If you want to allow access to "public" page, you just need to add them in the
redirect option. Alternatively, you can enable the redirect only for certain routes using the
Ensure to activate the authentication providers you want in the Supabase Dashboard under
The log-in page initiates the log-in method(s) you choose from the
provided by Supabase, it could looks like:

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight

children.value: Once the authorization flow is triggered using the
composable, the session management is handled automatically and the user will be redirected to the page you specify in the redirect option (
The confirmation page receives the supabase callback. From there you can check the user value and redirect to the appropriate page.
The redirect URL must be configured in your Supabase dashboard under

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight

children.value: You can easily handle redirection to the initial requested route after login.
to allow cookie storage and take benefit of this feature.

contents.title: useSupabaseClient
contents.description: Make requests to the Supabase API with the useSupabaseClient composable

children.value: your client inside your vue files.
under the hood, it gives access to the
The client is initialized with the
file. It establishes the connection with the database and make use of user JWT to apply
implemented in Supabase. If you want to bypass policies, you can use the
The useSupabaseClient composable is providing all methods to manage authorization under
. For more details please see the
. Here is an example for signing in and out:
If you want a full explanation on how to handle the authentication process, please read this

props.className: language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
const supabase = useSupabaseClient()

const signInWithOAuth = async () => {
  const { error } = await supabase.auth.signInWithOAuth({
    provider: 'github',
    options: {
      redirectTo: 'http://localhost:3000/confirm',
    },
  })
  if (error) console.log(error)
}

const signOut = async () => {
  const { error } = await supabase.auth.signOut()
  if (error) console.log(error)
}
</script>

children.value: Please also take a look at
documentation to fully use the power of Supabase client.
Here is an example of a fetch using the

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
const client = useSupabaseClient()

const { data: restaurant } = await useAsyncData('restaurant', async () => {
  const { data } = await client.from('restaurants').select('name, location').eq('name', 'My Restaurant Name').single()

  return data
})
</script>

children.value: , listen to changes in your PostgreSQL Database and broadcasts them over WebSockets.
To enable it, make sure you have turned on the
Then, listen to changes directly in your vue page / component:

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
import type { RealtimeChannel } from '@supabase/supabase-js'

const client = useSupabaseClient()

let realtimeChannel: RealtimeChannel

// Fetch collaborators and get the refresh method provided by useAsyncData
const { data: collaborators, refresh: refreshCollaborators } = await useAsyncData('collaborators', async () => {
  const { data } = await client.from('collaborators').select('name')
  return data
})

// Once page is mounted, listen to changes on the `collaborators` table and refresh collaborators when receiving event
onMounted(() => {
  // Real time listener for new workouts
  realtimeChannel = client.channel('public:collaborators').on(
    'postgres_changes',
    { event: '*', schema: 'public', table: 'collaborators' },
    () => refreshCollaborators()
  )

  realtimeChannel.subscribe()
})

  // Don't forget to unsubscribe when user left the page
onUnmounted(() => {
  client.removeChannel(realtimeChannel)
})
</script>

children.value: // Fetch collaborators and get the refresh method provided by useAsyncData
// Once page is mounted, listen to changes on the `collaborators` table and refresh collaborators when receiving event
// Real time listener for new workouts
// Don't forget to unsubscribe when user left the page
Database typings are passed to the client out of the box if the database generated types are found at

props.className: language-shell shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
## Generate types from live database
supabase gen types typescript --project-id YourProjectId > types/database.types.ts

## Generate types when using local environment
supabase gen types typescript --local > types/database.types.ts

children.value: ## Generate types when using local environment
You can also pass Database typings to the client manually:

props.className: language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
import type { Database } from '~/types'
const client = useSupabaseClient<Database>()
</script>

which returns just the User information of the session.

children.value: html .light .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-light);background: var(--shiki-light-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-light-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-light-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-light-text-decoration);}html.light .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-light);background: var(--shiki-light-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-light-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-light-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-light-text-decoration);}html .default .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-default);background: var(--shiki-default-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-default-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-default-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-default-text-decoration);}html .dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}html.dark .shiki span {color: var(--shiki-dark);background: var(--shiki-dark-bg);font-style: var(--shiki-dark-font-style);font-weight: var(--shiki-dark-font-weight);text-decoration: var(--shiki-dark-text-decoration);}
